title: Cat. 22  Little Court, Cloth Fair, 1887
publication_title: The Lithographs of James McNeill Whistler: The Digital Edition
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section body" id="body"> 221887Way: 18  
Levy: 29  
Transfer lithograph, drawn on coarse-grained transfer paper  
Ink color: black  
Signature: printed butterfly, center right  
One state; image size: 192 × 95 mm  
Number of impressions listed by Way: 12  
Printer: Way  
Watermarks: 41, 42, 166, 190, 191, 272–74, 280  
Posthumous edition: 32 impressions printed by Goulding on 12 November 1903  
Posthumous watermarks: 50, 54, 209, 219, 220, 280, 294, 295, 300  
Stone: erased in 1903  
Whistler-Way Letters: 34, 35, 86, 152; apps. I.1, III.2, V.1  
Selected Literature: Way, Studio (1896), p. 223; Pennell (1897), p. 287; Way (1912), pp. 88–89  
Lifetime Exhibitions: London 1895–96 (no. 38); New York 1898 (no. 300); Chicago 1900b (no. 15)

On 17 August 1887 The World reported that “pencil and notebook in hand, [Whistler] was discovered the other morning in the purlieus of the Minories sketching the picturesque corners of ‘Cloth Fair’.” The press notice almost certainly preceded the artist’s execution of this lithograph; it was not until September that Way sent him a block of transfer paper and lithographic crayons.

In this lithograph Whistler depicted one of the small courts in Cloth Fair, in the St. Bartholomew neighborhood, focusing on a group of figures clustered in front of the shops at the far end of the court. The compositional device used here is one that he had developed while working in Venice: one principal area of interest is treated in detail, and surrounding areas are depicted in a more cursory style. Little Court, Cloth Fair has more contrast than Whistler’s other lithographs of St. Bartholomew sites (cat. 20 and cat. 21), suggesting that the artist may have been working with softer crayons. A similar approach to scale, composition, and subject matter is found in Fleur de Lys Passage (K 289), one of several etchings Whistler made in this neighborhood at about the same time.

Chicago: AIC, ivory laid paper (322 × 206 mm), signed; MWC, cream laid paper (309 × 202 mm), signed; Palmer, ivory wove paper (318 × 200 mm), signed; SC, ivory wove paper (317 × 202 mm). Glasgow: HAG (3), ivory laid paper (323 × 207 mm), signed; grayish ivory chine (209 × 106 mm) mounted on ivory plate paper (384 × 279 mm); cream laid paper (319 × 206 mm). London: BM, grayish white chine (210 × 107 mm) mounted on white plate paper (361 × 240 mm). Washington: FGA (2), grayish white chine (209 × 106 mm) mounted on white plate paper (382 × 280 mm); cream laid paper (317 × 205 mm); NGA, cream Japanese paper (289 × 221 mm).

Remarks: Other impressions are found in Brooklyn, TBM; and New York, MMA.  
Nesta R. Spink, Harriet K. Stratis, Martha Tedeschi

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">Quoted in MacDonald (1976), p. 24, no. 34.

See letter 18.

Beatrix Whistler was probably referring to this image when she asked Way to print more impressions of St. Bartholomew’s Court in. May 1892; letter 34.
